Network traffic involving suspicious dom.Action: Analyze Zeek http.log and dns.log for connections to newly registered domains or domains with low reputation. Use statistical analysis on domain/URL entropy or n-gram analysis on request patterns to identify potentially AI-generated network destinations. Correlate with threat intelligence feeds for suspicious domains.

Execution attempts of obfuscated scripts.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 4104
Execution attempts of obfuscated scripts.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 (process creation) and 4104 (PowerShell logging) for execution of highly obfuscated or unusually structured script content. Apply entropy analysis or machine learning heuristics designed to detect AI-generated or heavily obfuscated malicious code patterns within script blocks.

Creation or modification of script or ex.Data: Windows Event ID 4656; Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 4104
Creation or modification of script or ex.Action: Monitor Windows Event IDs 4656 (filtered for file writes to suspicious locations or types), 4688 (for compiler/script interpreter processes), and 4104 (for PowerShell content). Correlate events to identify instances of rapid creation, modification, or compilation of scripts/executables, especially those with high entropy or unusual naming patterns, potentially indicative of automated generation workflows. Use time series analysis or frequency analysis to detect bursts of such activity.

Download of potentially malicious or unu.Action: Monitor Zeek http.log for file downloads (.exe, .dll, .ps1, .py, .sh, archives) from potentially suspicious or low-reputation domains identified via threat intelligence or statistical analysis (e.g., domain age, entropy). Correlate download events with preceding or concurrent web browsing activity (Zeek http.log, conn.log) to sites known for code snippets, forums, or hosting suspicious content. Use frequency analysis or correlation analysis to identify rare combinations of browsing patterns and subsequent downloads.
